screenplay.rawText:
INT. JASON’S ART STUDIO – MORNING
Jason sets up a plastic folding table, moves the commission onto it, and begins the slow, meticulous illustration phase. A random guy interrupts asking if the studio is a bike shop. Jason and Stacey discuss time-lapse footage and the nature of his 'Illustrated Abstraction' style.
actions: Jason unfolds and sets up a plastic table in the center of the studio.
He assesses the work-in-progress painting on the wall.
He removes the painting from the wall and positions it flat on the table.
A random man appears at the open studio door asking if it's a bike shop.
Jason gives a dry, comedic response and the man leaves confused.
Jason and Stacey discuss using time-lapse for this slower process.
Jason prepares dropper bottles, gloves, and paint in tiny plastic shot glasses.
He explains the purpose of the illustration phase.
Jason studies the brush strokes with intense concentration.
He begins laying down detailed line-work.
A long painting session (2 hours) unfolds, partially shown as a time-lapse.
Stacey asks about the origin of the style name 'Illustrated Abstraction.'
Jason explains the combination of colorfield, action painting, and illustration.

lines: There.. That’ll give me enough room to walk around the painting.
It feels good to see a work-in-progress the next day, and still like it.. ..Sometimes that’s not the case.
It’s much easier to work on it like this.. It’s better to lie it flat for this part.
That’s right.. I was a bike shop 5 or 6 years ago. But now—— no bikes.
You’d be surprised how often that happens.
You’re probably going to time-laps this part.

Day one and day two of painting was just the start. That part is fast. This part is much slower.. The line-work here is tedious.. I’d estimate this part taking 30 to 50 hours to be completely finished. Plus, I’m usually good for about 2 or 3 hours of painting at a time.. Time-laps footage will be more interesting.. No need to bore anyone.
This is where I illustrate the abstracted brush strokes that I painted yesterday. I do this by outlining the brush strokes and add in various details..
This should be fun!.. It always is.

I love colorfield paintings.. That’s where I started. That’s what I was doing on day one. I also love action paintings—— also known as abstract expressionism. That’s mostly what I did with the large brush strokes on day two. Now I’m onto the illustration phase. It’s drawing basically. Drawing brush strokes.
Hey, is this a bike shop?
So it’s not a bike shop?
Yeah, no problem.. I’ll edit it down to keep it interesting.
How do you describe this part of your process?
Tell me about why you call this style Illustrated Abstraction.

narrative.summary: Jason begins the detailed illustration phase, explaining its purpose and complexity. A humorous interruption occurs when a man mistakes the studio for a bike shop. Jason elaborates on his artistic lineage and work ethic while Stacey captures footage.
narrative.beatPurpose: Deep character development through artistic exposition; show the shift from expressive chaos to precision detail; add humor via interruption; reinforce the documentary dynamic.
narrative.conflict: Internal: Jason must remain focused during slow, tedious work. External: interruptions and ongoing stress from the studio environment.
narrative.stakes: Maintaining workflow over long hours; staying mentally sharp through a slow, detail-oriented stage crucial to the commission.
narrative.outcome: Jason completes a portion of the line-work and ends the day satisfied.

revealedBackstory: Jason's studio used to be a bike shop 5–6 years ago.
Jason’s style integrates colorfield, action painting, and illustration.

continuityLinks: Reveals Jason’s earlier business history as a bike shop owner.
Deepens the understanding of his artistic process and philosophy.
Shows Stacey continuing documentation for the eventual documentary.

music: Warm contemplative cue during Jason’s explanations
cameraIdeas: Time-lapse overhead wide shot of Jason painting
Rack focus from Jason to painting strokes
Comedic cutaway when Jason stares into camera after Random Guy's question
setRequirements: Studio door visible for Random Guy entrance
